metadata.case_name: Vanguards Fire & General Insurance Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The appellant, Vanguards Fire & General Insurance Co., carried on fire and general insurance business.
It owned a building of which a part was occupied by the assessee for its own business, the rest being let out on rent.
During the previous year ending December 31, 1949 (assessment year 1950-51), the assessee received a sum of Rs. 8,230 as rent on the portion let out.
In the accounting year ending December 31, 1950 (assessment year 1951-52), the rent received amounted to Rs. 37,200.
The Income-tax Officer excluded these amounts from assessment in view of section 4(3)(xii) of the Act.
The Commissioner of Income-tax issued a notice to the assessee under Section 33B of the Act to show cause why the orders of the Income-tax Officer should not be modified.
Commissioner held that only income chargeable under the head 'income from property' is entitled to exemption under section 4(3)(xii), not income chargeable under the Schedule for insurance companies.
Assessee appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal which upheld the order of the Commissioner.

Tribunal observed: 'The exemption under section 4(3)(xii) is to the income received from property and as the income in the instant case is from insurance business, the assessee cannot lay claim to any exemption under this sub-section.'
Further, 'the Schedule in dealing with life insurance makes some mention of income from property (section 9), while the absence of any such mention in general insurance is significant.'
At the instance of the assessee, the Appellate Tribunal stated a case and referred the question to the High Court under section 66.
High Court answered the question in the affirmative and against the assessee.
Two appeals by special leave directed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras.

legal_issues.text: Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the rental income from the house property received by the assessee for the assessment years 1950-51 and 1951-52 is not exempt under section 4(3)(xii) of the Act notwithstanding section 10(7) of the Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: By virtue of section 4(3)(xii), the income from property cannot be included in the total income of the assessee, and section 10(7) does not exclude the applicability of section 4(3)(xii).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 4(3)(xii); section 10(7) non-obstante clause does not include sections 4 and 6

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 4(3)(xii) is applicable because although the income from property in the case of a general insurance company is computed in accordance with the Schedule, yet it is still chargeable under the head 'income from property', and there is no practical difficulty in granting exemption.

respondent_arguments.text: An insurance company is assessed on a national basis and the national figure arrived at in accordance with the Schedule cannot be varied by anything contained in section 4 of the Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 10(7) and paragraph 6 of the Schedule

respondent_arguments.text: The income from property is not computed in accordance with section 9 and is not chargeable under the head 'income from property' but is included and charged as a composite thing, i.e., the profits and gains of the business of insurance.

court_reasoning.text: Insurance companies are assessed on a special basis under section 10(7) read with the Schedule; for general insurance, paragraph 6 applies, taking balance of profits from annual accounts furnished under Insurance Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: There is no income chargeable under the head 'Income from property' as far as a general insurance business is concerned.

court_reasoning.text: The effect of section 10(7) is to delete the heads 'Interest on securities, Income from property and Income from other sources' from section 6 as far as general insurance businesses are concerned.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It is equally impossible to apply the provisions of section 4(3)(xii) to an assessment made under section 10(7), read with paragraph 6 of the Schedule.

court_reasoning.text: In life insurance, Schedule mentions income from property, but absence in general insurance is significant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rents in revenue account for general insurance are actual rents received, not annual value under section 9.

holdings.text: The rental income is not exempt under section 4(3)(xii) notwithstanding section 10(7); answer to the question is in the affirmative and against the assessee.

precedents_cited.case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessment of insurance business completely governed by Schedule; no power to correct errors outside it.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pandyan Insurance Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Insurance Act ensures true valuation; no power to adjust accounts on revaluation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Western India Life Insurance Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Privy Council held proviso to s.4(1) does not apply to life insurance assessment under Schedule.

precedents_cited.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Australian Mutual Provident Society
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between assessment on actual income and notional income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Asian Assurance Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay High Court reached same conclusion.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Rental income not exempt under s.4(3)(xii) for general insurance business assessed under s.10(7) and Schedule.

statutes_cited.name: Insurance Act, 1938
statutes_cited.relevance: Annual accounts furnished to Superintendent of Insurance used for computing profits.

outcome.summary: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs. High Court's answer upheld: rental income not exempt under section 4(3)(xii) notwithstanding section 10(7).
